name: Nairobi National Park
description: A wildlife reserve located just outside Nairobi's central business district.
fun_facts: It is the only national park within a capital city in the world where you can see lions, giraffes, and rhinos.
fees: Local Adults: KES 1,000, Adult Foreigners: US$ 80

name: Giraffe Centre
description: A conservation and education center home to endangered Rothschild giraffes.
fun_facts: Visitors can feed giraffes by hand and learn about conservation efforts.
fees: Resident Adults: KES 400, Foreign Adults: KES 1,500

name: Karura Forest
description: An urban forest with trails, waterfalls, caves, and picnic areas.
fun_facts: The forest was declared a protected area in 1999 and is home to over 200 species of birds.
fees: Local Adults: KES 100, Residents: KES 200, Non-residents: KES 600

name: Nairobi National Museum
description: Kenya's flagship museum showcasing culture, nature, and history.
open_hours: Daily: 8:30 AM – 5:30 PM (including public holidays). Night tours available for organized groups by advance booking (6:00 PM – 10:00 PM).
fun_facts: Features the **Hall of Human Origins**, showcasing significant fossil finds from Koobi Fora. The complex also includes the **Snake Park** and beautiful **Botanical Gardens**.
fees: Non-residents: Adults ~$8.00 (Ksh 1,200), Children ~$4.00 (Ksh 600). Citizens: Adults Ksh 200, Children Ksh 100.

name: Karen Blixen Museum
description: Historic farmhouse of the famous author of 'Out of Africa'.
open_hours: Daily: 8:30 AM – 5:30 PM (including weekends and public holidays).
fun_facts: The farmhouse and surrounding coffee plantation were the setting for her memoir, 'Out of Africa'. You can view many of the original furnishings.
fees: Non-residents: Adults ~$8.00 (Ksh 1,200), Children ~$4.00 (Ksh 600). Citizens: Adults Ksh 200, Children Ksh 100.

name: Railway Museum
description: A museum showcasing Kenya's railway history, including vintage locomotives.
fun_facts: The museum houses the carriage where the colonial official, Charles Ryall, was dragged out and eaten by the famous **Maneaters of Tsavo** lions in 1900.
fees: Non-residents: Adults Ksh 600, Children Ksh 300. Citizens: Adults Ksh 200, Children/Students Ksh 100.

name: Kenyatta International Conference Centre (KICC)
description: An iconic tower known for its rooftop views of Nairobi.
open_hours: Daily: Typically 8:00 AM – 6:00 PM (for rooftop access).
fun_facts: The tower is shaped like a **traditional African hut** with a revolving restaurant on top (currently under renovation). Its 28-story structure is one of the most recognizable buildings in Nairobi.
fees: Rooftop Viewpoint Access: Residents/EAC Citizens ~$5-$7, Non-residents ~$10.

name: Bomas of Kenya
description: A cultural center showcasing Kenya's tribes through performances and exhibits.
open_hours: Park: Weekdays 8:00 AM – 5:00 PM, Weekends/Holidays 8:30 AM – 6:00 PM. Cultural Shows: Weekdays 2:30 PM, Weekends/Holidays 3:30 PM.
fun_facts: The word 'Bomas' means **'homesteads'** in Swahili, and the site features authentic replica traditional villages from many of Kenya's diverse ethnic groups.
fees: Citizen Entry: Adults Ksh 200, Child Ksh 50. Non-Resident Entry: Adults Ksh 1,000, Child Ksh 500. *Cultural show is an extra charge (e.g., Citizen ~Ksh 500, Non-Resident ~Ksh 1,000).*

name: Uhuru Gardens National Monument
description: Kenya's largest memorial park marking the country's independence.
open_hours: Daily: Typically 8:00 AM – 6:00 PM (The new National Monument and Museum complex has specific operating hours).
fun_facts: The site is where Kenya's first flag was raised at midnight on **December 12, 1963**, marking independence. 'Uhuru' is Swahili for 'Freedom'.
fees: Entry to the park/museum is often cited as free, but a fee may apply for the recently renovated museum section and for activities like parking or photography/filming.

name: August 7th Memorial Park
description: A peace memorial dedicated to victims of the 1998 US Embassy bombing.
open_hours: Park: Daily 6:00 AM – 6:00 PM. Museum: Mon-Sat 9:00 AM – 6:00 PM, Sun/Holidays 1:00 PM – 6:00 PM.
fun_facts: The park's design incorporates an indigenous garden and a Yin-Yang fountain, symbolizing peace and unity in the wake of the tragedy.
fees: Park Entry: Typically Ksh 50 per person. Museum Entry: Additional fee, e.g., Residents Ksh 100, Non-Residents Ksh 150.

name: David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust (DSWT)
description: Elephant and rhino orphanage famous for rehabilitating baby elephants.
fun_facts: Visitors can watch the baby elephants being fed milk and playing in the mud, with handlers sharing personal stories about each orphan.
fees: Non-Citizen/Resident Adult: KES 1,500 (or USD 15). Citizen Adult: KES 500.

name: Mamba Village Nairobi
description: A popular crocodile farm and resort in the Karen area.
fun_facts: Mamba Village is home to hundreds of Nile crocodiles, and visitors can witness feeding time and learn about the reptiles.
fees: Citizen Adult: KES 250, Non-Resident Adult: USD 10

name: Nairobi Arboretum
description: A tranquil urban forest reserve with over 350 species of trees.
fun_facts: Established in 1907, it's a major green space in the city, popular for jogging, picnics, and bird watching. It covers about 30 hectares.
fees: Citizen Adult: KES 65, Non-Resident Adult: KES 100

name: Kazuri Beads & Pottery Centre
description: A workshop creating handmade ceramic beads and pottery, providing employment for disadvantaged women.
fun_facts: Kazuri means 'small and beautiful' in Swahili. It was started in 1975 to provide and sustain employment for single mothers and disadvantaged women.
fees: Free entry/tour (no obligation to buy)

name: National Archives (Kenya)
description: Houses the public records of the Kenyan government and a gallery of African art.
fun_facts: The basement gallery features the Murumbi African Heritage Collection, one of the largest Pan-African art collections in the world.
fees: Citizen Adult: KES 50, Non-Citizen Adult: KES 200

name: Nairobi Gallery
description: A museum dedicated to showcasing contemporary and traditional Kenyan art and cultural artifacts.
fun_facts: The building was the former Provincial Commissioner's Office and the 'Point Zero' of Nairobi, from which distances were measured.
fees: Citizen Adult: KES 150, Resident Adult: KES 600, Non-Resident Adult: KES 1,000

name: African Heritage House
description: An architectural masterpiece overlooking Nairobi National Park, housing a huge Pan-African art collection.
fun_facts: Designed by Alan Donovan and inspired by the mud architecture of African nations, it is a protected national monument.
fees: Day Tour: USD 25-30 (includes lunch or snacks, varies by package)

name: Maasai Market (Various Locations)
description: A vibrant open-air market for authentic African curios, jewelry, and art.
open_hours: Daily, rotates location (e.g., Sat at High Court, Sun at Yaya Centre, Tue at Kijabe Street)
fun_facts: The market moves to a different location in the city almost every day of the week, allowing vendors to reach different customers.
fees: Free entry

name: City Market
description: A permanent indoor market for meat, fresh produce, and a wide variety of souvenirs and crafts.
fun_facts: It is an historic landmark in the city center and a reliable spot for purchasing affordable wood carvings and stone sculptures.
fees: Free entry

name: Uhuru Park & Central Park
description: Two adjacent public parks offering a green escape, boating, and relaxation spots in the city centre.
fun_facts: Uhuru Park (Freedom Park) has a prominent man-made lake and a popular assembly ground for political rallies and public events.
fees: Free entry

name: Nairobi Safari Walk
description: A boardwalk that offers a taste of Kenyan wildlife (including the Big Five) on a raised viewing platform.
fun_facts: It is an important educational facility that allows visitors to observe animals in a natural, confined environment.
fees: Citizen Adult: KES 215, Resident Adult: KES 215, Non-Resident Adult: USD 22

name: Nairobi Snake Park
description: Adjacent to the National Museum, showcasing snakes, crocodiles, and other reptiles.
fun_facts: It hosts both venomous and non-venomous snakes found in Kenya, alongside fish, tortoises, and other small animals.
fees: Citizen Adult: KES 100, Resident Adult: KES 400, Non-Resident Adult: KES 600 (Can be combined with Museum ticket)

name: Utamaduni Craft Centre
description: A permanent collection of boutique craft shops housed in a charming, traditional-style building.
fun_facts: The centre is popular for high-quality, authentic Kenyan and African artifacts, fabrics, and jewelry from various vendors.
fees: Free entry

name: Shifteye Gallery
description: A dynamic gallery in the city centre showcasing contemporary African photography and art.
fun_facts: It often features rotating exhibitions by emerging and established artists across different mediums.
fees: Free entry

name: GoDown Arts Centre
description: A hub for contemporary performance and visual arts, housed in a renovated warehouse.
fun_facts: The centre provides space for artists to rehearse, create, and showcase their work, hosting various festivals and workshops.
fees: Free entry (Fees apply for specific events/shows)

name: One Off Contemporary Art Gallery
description: A tranquil gallery space known for exhibiting contemporary East African painting and sculpture.
fun_facts: The gallery is set within a serene garden, making the visit a peaceful artistic escape.
fees: Free entry

name: Jomo Kenyatta Mausoleum
description: The final resting place of Kenya's first president, Mzee Jomo Kenyatta.
open_hours: Visitable from the outside 24/7. Interior access is highly restricted.
fun_facts: The mausoleum is guarded 24 hours a day by uniformed military personnel, who conduct a formal change of guard ceremony.
fees: Free to view the exterior

name: Tom Mboya Statue
description: A statue honouring the assassinated Kenyan politician Tom Mboya.
fun_facts: Tom Mboya was a brilliant young minister assassinated in 1969. The statue is a major point of reference and a popular photo spot in the CBD.
fees: Free

name: Dedan Kimathi Monument
description: A memorial honouring Dedan Kimathi, a Mau Mau leader executed during the struggle for independence.
fun_facts: The statue depicts Kimathi raising a gun and holding a panga (machete), symbolizing the armed resistance against the colonial government.
fees: Free

name: Jamia Mosque
description: One of Nairobi's most prominent religious structures, known for its intricate Arabic architecture.
open_hours: Daily (Visitor access may be restricted outside of prayer times)
fun_facts: It features three silver domes and two minarets. It is the central hub for the Muslim community in Nairobi.
fees: Free (Donations accepted)

name: Holy Family Basilica
description: The main Catholic church in Nairobi, known for its modernist architecture and stained glass.
open_hours: Daily (Visitor access may be restricted outside of service times)
fun_facts: The church was visited by Pope John Paul II in 1980 and 1995, and has a capacity of over 3,000 people.
fees: Free (Donations accepted)

name: The National Theatre
description: Kenya's main venue for performing arts, hosting plays, concerts, and cultural events.
open_hours: Mon-Fri: 09:00 - 17:00 (Box office/general), Event-dependent in the evenings
fun_facts: It is home to the Kenya Cultural Centre and the Kenya National Theatre, offering a stage for both local and international performances.
fees: Free entry (Fees apply for specific events/shows)

name: The Carnivore Restaurant
description: A famous open-air restaurant known for its 'Dawa' cocktail and all-you-can-eat meat feast (including game meat).
fun_facts: The meats are roasted on gigantic Maasai swords over a charcoal pit. The signature drink, 'Dawa', means 'medicine' in Swahili.
fees: Dinner/Lunch per person: KES 4,500 - 6,000 (Non-Resident price is often USD 45-60)

name: Talisman Restaurant
description: An upscale restaurant in Karen set in a charming converted farmhouse with beautiful gardens.
fun_facts: Known for its fusion cuisine and bohemian atmosphere, it is a favorite dining spot for expatriates and residents.
fees: Free entry (Cost is for meals/drinks)

name: Kitengela Glass
description: A magical glassblowing studio and sanctuary creating art from recycled glass.
fun_facts: The entire compound, including bridges, pathways, and houses, incorporates recycled glass and features whimsical, fantasy-like sculptures.
fees: Citizen Adult: KES 200, Non-Resident Adult: KES 400

name: Amani Ya Juu
description: A social enterprise that trains and employs refugee and disadvantaged women to create beautiful fabric crafts.
fun_facts: The name means 'Peace from Above'. The centre has a beautiful garden cafe where visitors can enjoy tea and snacks.
fees: Free entry

name: Two Rivers Mall - Eye of Kenya
description: The largest shopping and entertainment complex in East Africa, featuring the 'Eye of Kenya' Ferris wheel.
fun_facts: The Eye of Kenya is Africa's tallest Ferris wheel, offering panoramic views of the northern suburbs of Nairobi.
fees: Mall entry free. Ferris Wheel: KES 500-800 per ride

name: The Hub Karen
description: A modern outdoor mall with diverse shopping, dining, and family entertainment options.
fun_facts: The mall has a large central lake and hosts family events, including a popular farmers' market.
fees: Free entry

name: Village Market
description: One of Nairobi's first modern shopping malls, designed with a focus on African architecture and open spaces.
fun_facts: The design includes waterfalls and a 'Market' area inspired by a traditional African village. It houses a bowling alley, cinema, and numerous international stores.
fees: Free entry

name: Nairobi Safari Park Hotel
description: A hotel resort famous for its 'Nyama Choma' (roast meat) and evening entertainment shows.
open_hours: Event dependent (Dinner and Show starts around 19:30)
fun_facts: The 'Safari Cats' show is a popular evening cultural performance of African music, acrobatics, and dance.
fees: Show & Dinner: KES 5,000 - 8,000 (Non-Resident price is often USD 60-100)

name: Kibera Art and Cultural Centre (KACC)
description: A community-based cultural center showcasing local art, music, and social issues.
fun_facts: The centre is an important hub for local youth and artists from the surrounding Kibera area, one of Africa's largest informal settlements.
fees: Free entry (Donations encouraged)

name: Karen Blixen Coffee Garden
description: A historic coffee garden and restaurant adjacent to the Karen Blixen Museum.
fun_facts: The restaurant is built on the grounds of Karen Blixen's original coffee farm and offers a serene, colonial-era dining experience.
fees: Free entry (Cost is for meals/drinks)

name: Nairobi Railway Station Clock Tower
description: An historic clock tower at the heart of the Nairobi Railway Station, a city landmark.
fun_facts: The station was the original terminus of the 'Lunatic Express' railway line that connected Mombasa to the interior.
fees: Free to view the exterior

name: Westgate Shopping Mall
description: A modern, upscale shopping and entertainment complex in Westlands.
fun_facts: It was the site of a tragic terrorist attack in 2013, but has been fully rebuilt and reopened as a symbol of resilience.
fees: Free entry

name: Parliament Buildings
description: The seat of the Kenyan government, featuring impressive architecture and the original Parliamentary chambers.
open_hours: Tours available on non-sitting days (Check with security)
fun_facts: The buildings include the towering clock tower and the debating chambers. The main structure was completed just before independence.
fees: Free (Requires prior arrangement and security clearance)

name: Supreme Court of Kenya
description: The highest court in Kenya, housed in a historic building with a large dome.
fun_facts: The building is a key piece of colonial-era architecture in the city centre. The court is famous for its judicial review of presidential elections.
fees: Free (View exterior)

name: Uhuru Gardens Museum Complex
description: A newly renovated, state-of-the-art museum dedicated to Kenya's history, culture, and independence struggle.
fun_facts: The museum complex is a recent addition to the Uhuru Gardens site, featuring interactive and multimedia exhibits.
fees: Citizen Adult: KES 200, Non-Resident Adult: KES 1,000

name: Nairobi Gallery of Photography
description: A small gallery dedicated to showcasing the work of Kenyan and African photographers.
fun_facts: It provides a visual history and contemporary view of Kenya through the lens of local artists.
fees: Free entry
